arch:property.oc:show_val: Associated with: Locus 6, and it extends to the northwest face of Locus 3.
Average Stylobate elevation: 904.486 m. Average floor elevation (top): 904.436 m.

Coarse, uneven, loose, reddish brown soil (Munsell 5YR 5/4) with a high concentration of mortar, plaster (particularly near the Temple Stylobate) and material culture (particularly small-sized architectural fragments). It is tipped approximately 15o from the south to the north. One object was cataloged; a corroded bronze spoon/spatula (93-M-1). Area to the north and west of the Temple Stylobate, encompassing the rest of what was formerly Locus 2. This locus was identified after all of the worked ashlar blocks were removed. Soil consistency initially remained the same, but the concentration of the collapse consisted primarily of carved limestone. Nearly all of the architectural fragments recovered from this locus were carved, capital fragments, carved attic column bases, carved frieze fragments, carved anta-bases or carved, limestone fragments of unknown use. Since the restorer believes that there is potential to reconstruct the capital, all carved pieces of limestone were saved and numbered. A limestone container was created for all uncarved pieces of limestone, so their quantity could be noted in comparison to the other types of material culture found. In Locus 7, a total of 92 architectural fragments were named, 64 of which were carved limestone. Although the placement of the carved fragments appears to be random, their position — most of the fragments were found near the north and west faces of the Stylobate in close proximity to one another — perhaps indicates that they fell to the ground prior to the collapse of the column drums. The entire locus area, however, was very rich in other material culture. There were five pottery, plaster and tile containers recovered, which included two painted, Nabataean sherds, neither of which had a distinguishable pattern, but were dated as Late Nabataean. The plaster found was highest in concentration around architectural fragments and in quantity far exceeding anything else from this locus. Tile fragments were minimal and none were large enough to determine what type of tile they were. Almost all of the shell found were very tiny pieces of mother-of-pearl and a few small, snail shells. The mother-of-pearl was recovered near the north face of the Temple Stylobate and near the collapsed drums from the West Porch column (Artie Column). Metal consisted of equal parts iron and iron slag, with very little bronze. Locus 7 also yielded the trench's only special find, a corroded, bronze libation spoon found near the base of the column drum P/ST 610 (near the northern extent of the locus. A few crude large white tesserae were recovered, apparently Byzantine. Very small fragments of opalescent glass were found and a piece of carnelian. Almost all of the stone recovered was flint. This locus also produced bone, including two teeth. In addition to the material culture, three architectural features were found. The first is a multi-colored, patchy, plaster floor that extends to the north face of the Temple Stylobate and to the west beyond it. Two sets of stairs were also found, the first of which also extends to the north face of the Stylobate and are found in the eastern part of Locus 7. They are of carved ashlar and appear to be ornamental because of the distance between the step height and the height of the Stylobate. The second set of stairs, located at the western edge of Locus 7, is approximately 1 m from the corner of the Stylobate. These stairs were not fully articulated, because they extend into Locus 8. They appear to be of the same course as the eastern stairs, although the intermediate blocks have been robbed. We anticipate that the West Staircase will be of the same design as those to the east, which match the stairs also found in Trench 1.
Closing elevation: 904.446 m at southwest, 904.426 m at northwest, 904.406 m at northeast, 904.436 m at center,
